content.question: Consider two velocity vectors <math alttext="vector v sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mtext>A</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="vector v sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mtext>B</mtext></msub></math> which have the same magnitude <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>s</mi></math> and different directions as shown in the figure. Which of the following correctly describes <math alttext="the absolute value of, vector v sub A, minus vector v sub B, end absolute value" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mpadded><mo>|</mo><mpadded><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mtext>A</mtext></msub><mo>−</mo><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>v</mi><mo>→</mo></mover><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mpadded><mo>|</mo></mpadded></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: A vector with a magnitude greater than zero and less than <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>s</mi></math>.
A vector with a magnitude equal to <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>s</mi></math>.
A vector with a magnitude greater than <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>s</mi></math>.

content.answer: A vector with a magnitude greater than <math alttext="s" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>s</mi></math>.

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
